segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 Well, thank you very much, everybody, for staying, actually.
I know you guys probably want to get out of here and enjoy the weather and have a nice
beer.
That's what I'm doing, actually, after this talk.
Well, thank you for coming.
My talk today is going to be introducing a little bit of the capabilities of the HELC,
which is a hunting elk.
It's a project that I've been working on since January, actually.
It was the first time that I made it public.
And this one is going to be focusing on one capability of the HELC, which is graph analytics
for effective threat hunting.
And since we were talking about graphs, I figured that would be probably, like, a clever
way to present myself, I guess.
So I'm a security analyst, part of the adversary team, Spector Ops.
And I also develop a few projects in GitHub.
If you have some time, I would love to get your feedback.
And one of them is the HELC, the 300 playbook, the OSIM, which is an open source security
metadata.
That one I'm still working on, making sure that I can come up with a standard schema
for SIEM.
So that way it's easier to share even rules and things like that and help also others
that are building their own SIEMs to understand that type of data that they're ingesting.
So today we're going to be talking about a little bit of, like, what effective threat
hunting is.
And we're going to go all the way from the, you know, history of graphing all the way
to the capabilities that actually Spark is providing to the HELC via graph frames.
And of course I'll show you a little bit of a future research of the tool itself.
But first I always like to talk about what actually effective threat hunting means.
And I feel that anybody can just put anything on that specific blank space, and it just
sounds badass.
Right?
Just anybody can just say it.
I actually use it for some of my blog posts.
But I started actually talking a little bit more into what effective really means.
And this connects directly with why is it that I started developing the HELC itself.
But the conversation that I had with my brother, actually, those that probably didn't know,
but that's my brother.
And he started talking to me in terms such as efficiency and efficacy.
And they're not the same, even though some people use it as if they were the same with
effectiveness.
The big difference is that with efficiency, you pretty much focus on the way how you're
going to utilize your resources.
How are you going to make the best out of your resources?
And efficacy is pretty much what everybody wants to do.
Right?
You want to find evil.
Right?
That's the objective.
But at the end, effectiveness is pretty much when you still get to your objective, but
you do it in a way that it's very efficient.
And sometimes, I would say, in the real world, it becomes the strategy that is the most economic
for your organization and for your team as well.
So when you talk about these terms now into detection or any type of, you know, let's
say, in this case, hunting programs, is when you start thinking how are you going to be
efficient.
And I think the MITRE team did a great job today when they were talking about how you
can start actually communicating, you know, with the blue team, red team and vice versa
when you start doing these purple engagements, trying to find a common model that you can
follow, such as MITRE ATT&CK.
So that's pretty much being efficient.
Right?
And at the same time, it's when you start focusing more into the type of technology
that you're going to be using, the people that you're going to be working with, the
right skills that they need training.
And at the end, at the end is the efficacy of this whole concept of effectiveness.
And here is when you have to be careful, because when you do any type of hunting engagement,
you don't just expect to find evil.
Some people just put that as a metric and unfortunately that, of course, messes your
metrics when you don't find anything and you just believe that you're not being efficient
at all.
So that's going to take us now to our next part, which now with these concepts, now you
kind of have an idea probably how the industry is actually going from a threat hunting perspective.
And everybody is just coming up with these nice methodologies, strategies, awesome programs,
all the way from pre-hunt activities where you start identifying data sources, the plan,
develop the hypotheses, you start hunting with some nice data analytics and stuff like
that, your lessons learned.
But I believe that everybody is just focusing so much into what is it that we need to do,
but they don't focus exactly what the problem probably is.
And everybody talks about the needle in the haystack, but I don't think that people are
understanding that their haystack is actually getting bigger.
And that's the big problem that I see a lot in this industry where everybody just wants
to do the cool stuff, right?
But then reality is that our data is just getting bigger and bigger that you have to
start coming up with different ways to approach this, how efficient you're going to be approaching
this specific problem.
So then it comes down into why then we start focusing even into graph analytics.
And we're going to get to it in a minute, but I think that that's because it has got
to the point where there is a lot of different tools out there, things that you can build
on your own, things you can buy, but they don't give you that flexibility where you
can start actually understanding your data in such a way that it becomes really intuitive
to find these patterns and things like that.
So this concept of, like, log it all and I want to have every single piece of data, unfortunately
it brings a lot of different problems also to your detection piece.
So the way I see it is that don't just try to find the needle in the haystack.
Try to find the relationships and the structural patterns between all these needles in the
haystack and at the same time identify the most interesting needles in the haystack.
And I think that that's pretty much what, in my opinion, the industry is moving towards
to.
And that's, of course, because of the amount of data that you have and the technology that
you need to use in order to approach this problem.
And that's when it starts the conversation of graph analytics because that's a specific
capability that would allow you to find these patterns and start identifying the most important
and interesting needles in the haystack in your environment.
So what is a graph?
And something simple.
How many here have done work with graph analytics or graph theory?
Anybody?
Raise your hand.
Oh, man.
All right.
That's good.
That's beyond what I was expecting.
So a graph is just a basic representation of your data.
And you start, you know, having nodes and also relationships between those nodes.
So formally a vertex and then you have an edge.
So in this case right here, I follow my brother.
My brother follows the health and health follows myself.
And here you can start seeing that a graph has also, you know, could be directed.
It could be actually a what's it called, direction both ways and things like that.
That's just a basic representation of your data.
Some basic terminology.
I actually attended a talk about graphing last week.
And it was really hard to follow a lot of different concepts.
And that's just because I was not aware of a few terms.
And that's what this slide is and the second one as well.
But this one just starts talking about a couple of things such as, for example, a path, a
walk.
And that's something that is going to be really useful when we start defining all these different
algorithms that you can use that red teamers are using and also blue teamers are using.
So just keep an eye on those terms.
These ones too.
For example, when you start talking about the adjacent, for example, vertex, pretty
much that's when you have a node.
You have an edge.
You have another node.
So node A is adjacent to node B. So some basic stuff.
Degrees and number of edges on a specific vertex, for example.
And the edges are the connections or the lines coming out of a vertex or a, for example,
edge coming in.
So you have an in degree and an out degree and things like that.
And neighbors, of course, you know, vertex that are related to each other.
For example, you can have a node and you have these two edges and you have your neighbors
in there.
So basic concepts that are going to be applied to what we're going to be talking in here.
But first let's talk about a little bit of the history of graph theory.
And all this started apparently in 1736 with Leonard, I think you say Euler, in Konigsberg.
So what's happening here is that the problem was that you have this beautiful city and
you have seven bridges in this city.
And the problem was how can you actually go through every, I would say, piece of land
across these bridges only once?
Like, is that actually even possible?
Leonard looked at it and then he started thinking about these seven bridges.
And then what he did is he just started considering each piece of land as if it was a node, a
vertex.
And then each bridge as if it was an edge, for example.
So from here he started thinking about the way how this can be connected.
And this was the basis of just graphing.
So what he did is he invented the Eulerian graph walk.
So we talked about walk a little bit, how you can start finding paths.
And what he started thinking is that when you start looking into this graph, it's impossible
to actually go through every single node� I'm sorry, through every single edge and node
once when the star and the end� I'm sorry.
When the star at the end, you have the other nodes in the middle.
And those two nodes are not odd numbers.
The number of edges is not an even number.
You cannot actually go through every single node once.
So what he did is he only took, for example, the one in the middle.
And you can see that from start to end, the number of edges is an odd number.
You have three in the start and then you have three at the end.
But then the other ones in the middle, actually, they are an even number.
You have four on the left and you have two on the right.
So that's just basic concept.
It started the conversation about how you can start approaching a specific problem with
graph and edges and things like that.
We started talking about specific type of graphs, like the indirect graphs and directed
graphs.
And these are just basic concepts, as you can see.
And this will be useful later when we talk about a couple algorithms.
Indirect graphs, basically, are just graphs that are connected to each other and they
don't necessarily will have a direction.
And the disconnected graphs in here, for example, you still have connected graphs, but you can
see that you're actually clustering your graph a little bit.
Even though it's called disconnected, you still do have two graphs that are connected.
And then you have, of course, weighted graphs.
And these are, for example, think about a GPS when it tries to find the place of where
to go and then it just calculates the distance.
That could be part of the weight of an edge, for example.
And a bipartite graph, basically, is when you want to start dividing your nodes and
you start creating this, for example, a bipartite graph that if you have one node and you have
one side and you have the other nodes that belong to a specific category, you can start
thinking about a star, for example.
And that's going to start pretty much putting us to the conversation into how can I use
a graph to start finding some type of reconnaissance and things like that.
For example, there is a new event.
Well, last year there was actually a specific event idea that came out where, you know,
which actually can help you to start enumerating the behavior of the tool Bloodhound.
And that one creates this very nice star graph when you start looking at it from a graph
perspective.
A walk and a path and a cycle.
An up and walk is basically a sequence of nodes connected by their edges.
And that just becomes a path.
But when the walk is a closed walk, that just becomes a circuit.
And then at the end that's also referred as a cycle.
Now, you might be asking to this point, like, how is this going to help me right now?
But believe me, like, understand these basic concepts into, like, what is the definition
of a path, of a cycle and things like that will make things much easier for us.
And at the end, of course, a cycle could be also determined by a I would say number
of nodes.
For example, you can have a triangle and things like that.
And a tree graph in here now, it's basically a graph that it's a little limited.
And when I say limited, it's because you have a root node and then you start going down
the path.
And within here, actually, it's very interesting.
Because when you think about a tree, you start going down your nodes.
But you don't necessarily go back to the same node and try to do all these loops and things
like that.
So when you start thinking about a tree, it's basically to start updating nodes, it's probably
to start exploring your paths and things like that.
Very useful because it's going to start taking us now to the analytics parts of graphing.
But when somebody talks about graph analytics now, after looking into the different types
of graphs, people keep thinking about graph analytics as just a graph query.
And that's pretty much what I've seen a lot, for example.
That people just think about into I'm just going to connect my node A, my B and my C
and I'll find my pattern, that's my analytic.
But analytic goes beyond that.
Actually, a graph query is just the first level of an analytic.
You have graph algorithms that would actually allow you to find some reasoning on your graph.
And in graph analytic itself, it's basically what it's going to take now, these results
from running your algorithms, and it starts giving you some type of statistics and things
like that, which would allow you to now get closer to what you want to do.
If you want to detect something, if you want to find a specific path and things like that.
So graph algorithms, now that we understand exactly what type of graphs we have and things
like that, pathfinding, centrality and community detection, pathfinding pretty much is which
you might be familiar a little bit with right now, which is when you start to use something
like Bloodhound and you find the shortest path from a local account to a domain admin,
for example, or to wherever you want to go, centrality basically determines the importance
of a specific vertex in the whole graph.
And community detection is the one that I like the most because it allows me to find
these specific islands in my graph, specific clusters that I could start actually investigating
a little bit more.
So when you start talking about pathfinding, now that we understand trees, now that we
understand paths, depth first search is one of the first algorithms that what it does,
as you can see here in the image, it just starts from the top of the tree, and then
it starts going deep into each node.
And what it does, it just uses this stacking process, which it starts in the top, goes
let's say to two, to three, and to four, and if it doesn't find the specific node that
it's trying to get, it's just going to go back and then try to go to the other nodes,
and then it starts touching everything.
So it goes deep into a specific node.
So the way how it goes is one, two, three, four, if I don't find anything, I just go
back my stack, and then I go five, six, seven, and then eight, and then nine, and then ten.
Now why is this important to understand?
Because if you see this methodology right here, if I'm looking for the node number ten
that is all the way to the right, I will have to go through every single node first, and
then I'll get to ten.
So that takes us to the other one, which is a little bit more efficient, which is the
breadth first search.
And this one, what it does, it just goes level by level.
So it starts going from the root node to the second level, it's going to touch the neighbors,
we talk about neighbors.
So you go one, two, three, four, go to the second level, five, six, seven, eight, and
then go to the third level, which I believe was six and, no, I think it was nine and ten.
There you go.
This is very important, because first it's more efficient, but you start actually touching
the whole graph at the same time, and this tends to be more efficient.
So when you start thinking about breadth first search, we talked about trees, as you can
see in there, but you can also have these also cycles connected to each other.
And it just follows the same strategy.
When you have a node A to a node H, and you start going one level and you say let me talk
to my neighbors, B and C, then I talk to D, F, and E, and you go so on, and then you start
finding the specific node that you want.
This is the basics of shortest path, because in here you start now understanding now that
I went through my whole graph with the breadth first search, I can now say in order for me
to go from H to A, all I have to do is go H, F, and then C, and then A, and then in
here you can also start applying weights, and this is how, you know, GPS works.
So, as you can see, like, it's very important to start understanding where everything comes
from in order to get to this specific algorithm, because this is the basics also of, you know,
Bloodhound.
And even though Bloodhound doesn't use weights at this point, because all it does is pretty
much finds the, you know, session at a different computer, and it just finds the writes that
you have on a different computer, and it just allows you to understand, like, what
is the path that you need to take, but it doesn't tell you take this path because the
weight is this number or, you know, take this other path.
It just pretty much applies the basic concept of the breadth first search, but that's technically
you can do it in the shortest path.
So as I was saying before, Bloodhound pretty much uses that basic methodology, but when
we start talking about now from a defensive perspective, you can start finding these,
you know, hidden paths in your network.
I was talking to a company before where they were explaining to me how they only had, let's
say, you know, 30 or 40 different domain admins, and when they started understanding exactly
these concepts into going through every single node in their environment, they, you know,
found out, you know, they had more than 50, of course.
So Bloodhound is, in my opinion, one of the best tools out there, which would allow you
to start understanding your paths from a defensive and also from an offensive perspective.
You can check these links.
For example, there's a blog post for the blue side, and there's a video also.
I think that one is from DEF CON.
Now as you can see, like, when I talk to somebody else about graph analytics and then blue teaming
and red teaming, they talk to me about Bloodhound, right?
But there is more in graph analytics that, in my opinion, starts now going more into
the blue side.
And when we talk about centrality, there are two algorithms that I like the most, which
is the PageRank and InDegree and OutDegree, and we talked about degree at the beginning
of the talk, but PageRank pretty much was invented by the co-founder of Google, and
this one was basically saying that if you have links from other sides that have a high
page rank, then you get a high page rank as well.
It's like a recursive type of algorithm.
And this one would start showing which nodes in your environment are the most important
based on the connections that, you know, the node has.
If we talk about InDegree and OutDegree, the basic definition of degree was the number
of edges that you have, InDegree are edges coming to you or to the node, and OutDegree
are edges leaving the node.
Very important because this will define, for example, from the InDegree side, if I have
a node in my environment that is just getting constant connections all at the same time,
it might be, for example, a node being used for exfiltration.
Or if you have an OutDegree, you might have some type of reconnaissance or you might have,
for example, bloodhound just going crazy and trying to find the specific path and shortest
path in your environment and things like that.
Community detection, strongly connected, and then we have also level propagation and triangle
counting.
And we come back to the concepts of having a disconnected graph and a connected graph.
So connected components basically will find these islands in your environment, and necessarily
it doesn't take direction when it starts creating these clusters.
Strongly connected, on the other hand, takes direction.
And here is where you can start finding these islands that are also connected to each other.
Because it's strongly connected, takes into consideration direction, but at the same time
it takes into consideration the fact that these nodes are also connected to each other
and there is a path going through every single node.
As you can see on the ones in the square, I can go around every single node, and the
other ones, even though they are still connected to the graph, there is not a path that can
go over those other vertices as well.
So very important algorithms to understand.
And then level propagation, it's more like applying a label or a tag to a specific node,
and then at the end it starts identifying communities in your environment just by understanding
the connections that it has and things like that.
So after going through all this stuff, you might be thinking, all right, so let's just
graph everything, right?
Because it just seems that that's the way to go.
Going back to the efficiency, let's be honest, right?
Organizations are not just ready putting all their logs into a graph database or just applying
graph to everything.
You have to understand where you can apply it and where you cannot apply it.
So that's why it's so important to start understanding what is it that you're trying to accomplish
with graphing.
And, of course, the technology piece is very important.
I haven't seen, for example, a Neo4j database being used as a primary sim, for example.
I haven't seen that.
It's probably happening, but you don't see that that often.
There are other components that will not allow you just to have that as your main database
and things like that.
So when I started thinking about what is it that I can do with open source and what
is it that I can start building in order to start understanding these concepts, but at
the same time to start using an infrastructure that organizations are already using, for
example, I've seen a few organizations already that I've been working with that use Elasticsearch
as their primary database, and it's� the concept was more I have to build something
that will align with what is it that is happening out there and what is it that people are using
out there.
So the architecture in here is pretty simple.
So you start basically with your endpoints on the left, and then it sends all the data
to Kafka, and Kafka is just basically a subscribe, publish type of technology where it just gathers
all the data, and then you have other technologies subscribing to Kafka topics, and then it pulls
the data.
In this case, we have Logstash, that it's a realtime pipeline technology with capabilities
that allows you to parse your data, transform it in any way you want.
It sends the data to Elasticsearch, and then the part that allows me to interact with Elasticsearch
is actually ESHadoop, which is an Elastic small stand-alone library that allows you
to execute Hadoop jobs on any type of database that has this library, for example, in this
case Elasticsearch.
But at the same time, it doesn't need Hadoop itself, like the infrastructure, to execute
these jobs.
So you can actually have something like Spark on the top, and that communicates directly
with Elasticsearch.
Then you have Kibana, which is just the interface to start querying and doing basic analytics
with Elasticsearch, and then we have also GraphFrames, which I'm going to be talking
about today, and then we have JupyterLab, which would allow me to have also an interface
where I can start documenting my procedures and things that I can do with my data.
So that's just a slide for reference that you guys are going to have later, so it just
talks about all the features that I talked about today.
And GraphFrames basically is just an Apache Spark package.
It's not part of Spark yet, and it just uses the Spark SQL APIs and also data frames.
Data frames are a tabular format of your data, so think about as an Excel sheet, you have
your columns, and then you have your rows, so that's the basic concept of a data frame.
And then this one, GraphFrames also uses a Cypher-like query to start also running graph
queries into your data.
And the way how it works is you have Elasticsearch with ESHadoop being like the bridge between
Spark and Elasticsearch, and then GraphFrames sits on the top of Spark SQL using Spark SQL
APIs and data frames, and then it just provides these graphing capabilities.
So how does GraphFrames compare to a graph database?
Well, Spark does not store data in a long term, so it's not a database.
So Spark GraphFrames is not going to store data either, and Spark is capable to build
all this graph computation via GraphFrames.
That's pretty much the difference.
Graph databases are totally different than just GraphFrames.
For example, Neo4j, you can still do your analytics, but they depend on each other.
With GraphFrames, you can sit on the top of Elasticsearch and other technologies.
So how do you build a graph with GraphFrames?
And this one takes the basic concepts also that we talked about today, and it just takes
two data frames, one which is going to be your vertices, your nodes, so in this case,
one to five, and then you have properties, the name, the age of the specific node, and
then you have the source and destination data frame.
You put those two, and then basically that will give you a graph where you will be able
to start running queries on the top of them, and as you can see, for those that have used
Neo4j, it has a cipher-like type of query.
You can see here from A to B, and then these names of A, A, B, and B are not necessarily
values.
It's pretty much where you're going to be naming your columns once you get your results.
And then GraphFrames also gives you graph algorithms, and as you can see, it touches
basically all the algorithms that we talked about today.
